 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.
 10 35    Sec. 7.  Section 902.1, subsection 1, Code 2017, is amended
 11  1 to read as follows:
 11  2      8  5 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse and the
  8  6 defendant did not intend to kill or anticipate that lethal
  8  7 force would be used.
  8  8    (7)  Any other factor which is relevant to the defendant's
  8  9 character or record or to the circumstances of the offense.
  8 10    d.  The state and the defendant or the defendant's counsel
  8 11 shall be permitted to present and cross=examine witnesses and
  8 12 present arguments for or against a sentence of death.  Evidence
  8 13 regarding aggravating and mitigating circumstances shall not
  8 14 be governed by the rules governing admissibility of evidence,
  8 15 except that introduction of evidence secured in violation of
  8 16 the Constitution of the United States or of the Constitution of
  8 17 the State of Iowa shall not be permitted.
  8 18    6.  At the conclusion of presentation of evidence in
  8 19 the penalty proceeding, the state and the defendant or the
  8 20 defendant's counsel shall be permitted to make closing
  8 21 arguments, including any rebuttal arguments, in the same manner
  8 22 as in the initial proceeding and the following issues shall be
  8 23 determined by the jury or the court if there is no jury:
  8 24    a.  Whether the aggravating circumstance or circumstances
  8 25 have been established beyond a reasonable doubt and outweigh
  8 26 any one or more mitigating circumstances.
  8 27    b.  Whether the defendant shall be sentenced to death.
  8 28    7.  A recommendation for a sentence of death shall not be
  8 29 permitted if the recommendation is based on the race, color,
  8 30 religious beliefs, national origin, or sex of the defendant
  8 31 or of any victim, or based on any other protected class under
  8 32 chapter 216.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  8 33 return of a finding in the penalty proceeding, if the matter
  8 34 is tried before a jury, the court shall instruct the jury
  8 35 that in considering whether a sentence of death is justified,
  9  1 the jury shall not consider race, color, religious beliefs,
  9  2 national origin, or sex of the defendant or of any victim, or
  9  3 consider any other protected class under chapter 216.  The
  9  4 court shall further instruct the jury that the jury shall not
  9  5 return a sentence of death unless the jury concludes that such
  9  6 a sentence would be recommended no matter what the race, color,
  9  7 religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other protected
  9  8 class of the defendant or of any victim may be.
  9  9    8.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  9 10 commencement of the jury deliberations in the penalty
  9 11 proceeding, the court shall instruct the jury that if the
  9 12 defendant is not sentenced to death, the court is required by
  9 13 law to impose a sentence of imprisonment until death without
  9 14 parole.  The court shall further instruct the jury that
  9 15 the sentence of imprisonment until death without parole is
  9 16 required by law if the jury fails to reach a unanimous verdict
  9 17 recommending a sentence of death.
  9 18    9.  Concurrently with the return of the findings on the
  9 19 issues submitted under subsection 6, the jury, or the court if
  9 20 there is no jury, shall return special verdicts as follows:
  9 21    a.  Which aggravating circumstances were established beyond a
  9 22 reasonable doubt and were considered in reaching the verdict.
  9 23    b.  Which mitigating circumstances were established and
  9 24 were considered in reaching the verdict returned on the issue
  9 25 specified in subsection 6, paragraph "a".
  9 26    10.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
  9 27 a unanimous affirmative finding on each of the issues submitted
  9 28 under subsection 6, paragraphs "a" and "b", the court shall
  9 29 enter a judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant
  9 30 to death as provided in section 902.1B.
  9 31    11.  However, if evidence that the defendant was not a
  9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.
 10 35    Sec. 7.  Section 902.1, subsection 1, Code 2017, is amended
 11  1 to read as follows:
 11  2      8 10    d.  The state and the defendant or the defendant's counsel
  8 11 shall be permitted to present and cross=examine witnesses and
  8 12 present arguments for or against a sentence of death.  Evidence
  8 13 regarding aggravating and mitigating circumstances shall not
  8 14 be governed by the rules governing admissibility of evidence,
  8 15 except that introduction of evidence secured in violation of
  8 16 the Constitution of the United States or of the Constitution of
  8 17 the State of Iowa shall not be permitted.
  8 18    6.  At the conclusion of presentation of evidence in
  8 19 the penalty proceeding, the state and the defendant or the
  8 20 defendant's counsel shall be permitted to make closing
  8 21 arguments, including any rebuttal arguments, in the same manner
  8 22 as in the initial proceeding and the following issues shall be
  8 23 determined by the jury or the court if there is no jury:
  8 24    a.  Whether the aggravating circumstance or circumstances
  8 25 have been established beyond a reasonable doubt and outweigh
  8 26 any one or more mitigating circumstances.
  8 27    b.  Whether the defendant shall be sentenced to death.
  8 28    7.  A recommendation for a sentence of death shall not be
  8 29 permitted if the recommendation is based on the race, color,
  8 30 religious beliefs, national origin, or sex of the defendant
  8 31 or of any victim, or based on any other protected class under
  8 32 chapter 216.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  8 33 return of a finding in the penalty proceeding, if the matter
  8 34 is tried before a jury, the court shall instruct the jury
  8 35 that in considering whether a sentence of death is justified,
  9  1 the jury shall not consider race, color, religious beliefs,
  9  2 national origin, or sex of the defendant or of any victim, or
  9  3 consider any other protected class under chapter 216.  The
  9  4 court shall further instruct the jury that the jury shall not
  9  5 return a sentence of death unless the jury concludes that such
  9  6 a sentence would be recommended no matter what the race, color,
  9  7 religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other protected
  9  8 class of the defendant or of any victim may be.
  9  9    8.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  9 10 commencement of the jury deliberations in the penalty
  9 11 proceeding, the court shall instruct the jury that if the
  9 12 defendant is not sentenced to death, the court is required by
  9 13 law to impose a sentence of imprisonment until death without
  9 14 parole.  The court shall further instruct the jury that
  9 15 the sentence of imprisonment until death without parole is
  9 16 required by law if the jury fails to reach a unanimous verdict
  9 17 recommending a sentence of death.
  9 18    9.  Concurrently with the return of the findings on the
  9 19 issues submitted under subsection 6, the jury, or the court if
  9 20 there is no jury, shall return special verdicts as follows:
  9 21    a.  Which aggravating circumstances were established beyond a
  9 22 reasonable doubt and were considered in reaching the verdict.
  9 23    b.  Which mitigating circumstances were established and
  9 24 were considered in reaching the verdict returned on the issue
  9 25 specified in subsection 6, paragraph "a".
  9 26    10.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
  9 27 a unanimous affirmative finding on each of the issues submitted
  9 28 under subsection 6, paragraphs "a" and "b", the court shall
  9 29 enter a judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant
  9 30 to death as provided in section 902.1B.
  9 31    11.  However, if evidence that the defendant was not a
  9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

  8 17 the State of Iowa shall not be permitted.
  8 18    6.  At the conclusion of presentation of evidence in
  8 19 the penalty proceeding, the state and the defendant or the
  8 20 defendant's counsel shall be permitted to make closing
  8 21 arguments, including any rebuttal arguments, in the same manner
  8 22 as in the initial proceeding and the following issues shall be
  8 23 determined by the jury or the court if there is no jury:
  8 24    a.  Whether the aggravating circumstance or circumstances
  8 25 have been established beyond a reasonable doubt and outweigh
  8 26 any one or more mitigating circumstances.
  8 27    b.  Whether the defendant shall be sentenced to death.
  8 28    7.  A recommendation for a sentence of death shall not be
  8 29 permitted if the recommendation is based on the race, color,
  8 30 religious beliefs, national origin, or sex of the defendant
  8 31 or of any victim, or based on any other protected class under
  8 32 chapter 216.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  8 33 return of a finding in the penalty proceeding, if the matter
  8 34 is tried before a jury, the court shall instruct the jury
  8 35 that in considering whether a sentence of death is justified,
  9  1 the jury shall not consider race, color, religious beliefs,
  9  2 national origin, or sex of the defendant or of any victim, or
  9  3 consider any other protected class under chapter 216.  The
  9  4 court shall further instruct the jury that the jury shall not
  9  5 return a sentence of death unless the jury concludes that such
  9  6 a sentence would be recommended no matter what the race, color,
  9  7 religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other protected
  9  8 class of the defendant or of any victim may be.
  9  9    8.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  9 10 commencement of the jury deliberations in the penalty
  9 11 proceeding, the court shall instruct the jury that if the
  9 12 defendant is not sentenced to death, the court is required by
  9 13 law to impose a sentence of imprisonment until death without
  9 14 parole.  The court shall further instruct the jury that
  9 15 the sentence of imprisonment until death without parole is
  9 16 required by law if the jury fails to reach a unanimous verdict
  9 17 recommending a sentence of death.
  9 18    9.  Concurrently with the return of the findings on the
  9 19 issues submitted under subsection 6, the jury, or the court if
  9 20 there is no jury, shall return special verdicts as follows:
  9 21    a.  Which aggravating circumstances were established beyond a
  9 22 reasonable doubt and were considered in reaching the verdict.
  9 23    b.  Which mitigating circumstances were established and
  9 24 were considered in reaching the verdict returned on the issue
  9 25 specified in subsection 6, paragraph "a".
  9 26    10.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
  9 27 a unanimous affirmative finding on each of the issues submitted
  9 28 under subsection 6, paragraphs "a" and "b", the court shall
  9 29 enter a judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant
  9 30 to death as provided in section 902.1B.
  9 31    11.  However, if evidence that the defendant was not a
  9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

  9 31    11.  However, if evidence that the defendant was not a
  9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

 11  1 to read as follows:
 11  2      8 21 arguments, including any rebuttal arguments, in the same manner

  9 20 there is no jury, shall return special verdicts as follows:
  9 21    a.  Which aggravating circumstances were established beyond a
  9 22 reasonable doubt and were considered in reaching the verdict.
  9 23    b.  Which mitigating circumstances were established and
  9 24 were considered in reaching the verdict returned on the issue
  9 25 specified in subsection 6, paragraph "a".
  9 26    10.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
  9 27 a unanimous affirmative finding on each of the issues submitted
  9 28 under subsection 6, paragraphs "a" and "b", the court shall
  9 29 enter a judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant
  9 30 to death as provided in section 902.1B.
  9 31    11.  However, if evidence that the defendant was not a
  9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.
 10 35    Sec. 7.  Section 902.1, subsection 1, Code 2017, is amended
 11  1 to read as follows:
 11  2      8 27    b.  Whether the defendant shall be sentenced to death.
  8 28    7.  A recommendation for a sentence of death shall not be
  8 29 permitted if the recommendation is based on the race, color,
  8 30 religious beliefs, national origin, or sex of the defendant
  8 31 or of any victim, or based on any other protected class under
  8 32 chapter 216.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  8 33 return of a finding in the penalty proceeding, if the matter
  8 34 is tried before a jury, the court shall instruct the jury
  8 35 that in considering whether a sentence of death is justified,
  9  1 the jury shall not consider race, color, religious beliefs,
  9  2 national origin, or sex of the defendant or of any victim, or
  9  3 consider any other protected class under chapter 216.  The
  9  4 court shall further instruct the jury that the jury shall not
  9  5 return a sentence of death unless the jury concludes that such
  9  6 a sentence would be recommended no matter what the race, color,
  9  7 religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other protected
  9  8 class of the defendant or of any victim may be.
  9  9    8.  After submission of the issues, but prior to the
  9 10 commencement of the jury deliberations in the penalty
  9 11 proceeding, the court shall instruct the jury that if the
  9 12 defendant is not sentenced to death, the court is required by
  9 13 law to impose a sentence of imprisonment until death without
  9 14 parole.  The court shall further instruct the jury that
  9 15 the sentence of imprisonment until death without parole is
  9 16 required by law if the jury fails to reach a unanimous verdict
  9 17 recommending a sentence of death.

 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.
 10 35    Sec. 7.  Section 902.1, subsection 1, Code 2017, is amended
 11  1 to read as follows:
 11  2      8 33 return of a finding in the penalty proceeding, if the matter
  8 34 is tried before a jury, the court shall instruct the jury

  9  6 a sentence would be recommended no matter what the race, color,
  9  7 religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other protected
  9  8 class of the defendant or of any victim may be.

  9 10 commencement of the jury deliberations in the penalty
  9 11 proceeding, the court shall instruct the jury that if the

  9 14 parole.  The court shall further instruct the jury that

 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

  9 24 were considered in reaching the verdict returned on the issue
  9 25 specified in subsection 6, paragraph "a".
  9 26    10.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
  9 27 a unanimous affirmative finding on each of the issues submitted
  9 28 under subsection 6, paragraphs "a" and "b", the court shall
  9 29 enter a judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant
  9 30 to death as provided in section 902.1B.
  9 31    11.  However, if evidence that the defendant was not a
  9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

 11  2      9 21    a.  Which aggravating circumstances were established beyond a
  9 22 reasonable doubt and were considered in reaching the verdict.
  9 23    b.  Which mitigating circumstances were established and
  9 24 were considered in reaching the verdict returned on the issue
  9 25 specified in subsection 6, paragraph "a".
  9 26    10.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
  9 27 a unanimous affirmative finding on each of the issues submitted
  9 28 under subsection 6, paragraphs "a" and "b", the court shall
  9 29 enter a judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant
  9 30 to death as provided in section 902.1B.
  9 31    11.  However, if evidence that the defendant was not a
  9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded
 10 19 on the jury verdict form and shall be read and recorded in open
 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.
 10 26 If, upon either the collective or the separate inquiry, any
 10 27 juror denies that the verdict is the juror's verdict, the court
 10 28 shall refuse to accept the verdict.  The court may direct
 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.
 10 35    Sec. 7.  Section 902.1, subsection 1, Code 2017, is amended
 11  1 to read as follows:
 11  2      9 32 major participant in the commission of the multiple offense
  9 33 of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section 902.15,
  9 34 and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a reckless
  9 35 indifference to human life is presented to the jury, or the
 10  1 court if there is no jury, the jury or the court shall also
 10  2 return a special verdict on the issue.  If the jury unanimously
 10  3 determines, or the court if there is no jury, finds that a
 10  4 preponderance of evidence exists that shows that the defendant
 10  5 was not a major participant in the commission of the multiple
 10  6 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 10  7 902.15, and that the defendant's conduct did not manifest a
 10  8 reckless indifference to human life, the court shall enter a
 10  9 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 10 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1, even if the jury or
 10 11 the court returns unanimous affirmative findings on each of the
 10 12 issues submitted under subsection 6.
 10 13    12.  If the jury, or the court if there is no jury, returns
 10 14 a negative finding on any of the issues submitted under
 10 15 subsection 6, paragraph "a" or "b", the court shall enter a
 10 16 judgment of conviction and shall sentence the defendant to life
 10 17 imprisonment as provided in section 902.1.
 10 18    13.  After a verdict has been rendered it shall be recorded

 10 20 court.  The jurors shall be collectively asked by the court
 10 21 whether the verdict returned is their true and correct verdict.
 10 22 Even though no juror makes any declaration to the contrary, the
 10 23 jury shall, if either party so requests, be polled and each
 10 24 juror shall be separately asked whether the verdict rendered by
 10 25 the jury foreperson is the juror's true and correct verdict.

 10 29 inquiry or permit inquiry by counsel to ascertain whether any
 10 30 juror has been subjected to coercion or has become confused
 10 31 during the jury deliberation process.  The court may, as
 10 32 appropriate, direct the jury to resume deliberation in the
 10 33 case.  If no disagreement on the verdict is expressed by any of
 10 34 the jurors, the court shall discharge the jury.

 11 16    Sec. 9.   11 15 are amended by striking the subsections.
 11 16    Sec. 9.   11 16    Sec. 9.   11 17 juveniles.
 11 18    1.  a.  Notwithstanding section 902.1, a defendant convicted
 11 19 of murder in the first degree in violation of section 707.2,
 11 20 and who was under the age of eighteen at the time the offense
 11 21 was committed shall receive one of the following sentences:
 11 22    (1)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 11 23 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 11 24 with no possibility of parole unless the governor commutes the
 11 25 sentence to a term of years.
 11 26    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 11 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 11 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 11 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 11 30    (3)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 11 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 11 32 with the possibility of parole.
 11 33    b.  (1)  The prosecuting attorney shall provide reasonable
 11 34 notice to the defendant, after conviction and prior to
 11 35 sentencing, of the state's intention to seek a life sentence
 12  1 with no possibility of parole under paragraph "a", subparagraph
 12  2 (1).
 12  3    (2)  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 12  4 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 12  5 following:
 12  6    (a)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 12  7 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 12  8 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 12  9 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 12 10 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 12 11    (b)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 12 12    (c)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 12 13 posed by the defendant.
 12 14    (d)  The degree of participation in the murder by the
 12 15 defendant.
 12 16    (e)  The nature of the offense.
 12 17    (f)  The defendant's remorse.
 12 18    (g)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 12 19    (h)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 12 20 following:
 12 21    (i)  The commission of the murder while participating in
 12 22 another felony.
 12 23    (ii)  The number of victims.
 12 24    (iii)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the murder,
 12 25 including whether the murder was the result of torture.
 12 26    (i)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 12 27 criminality of the conduct.
 12 28    (j)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 12 29 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 12 30    (k)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 12 31    (l)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 12 32    (m)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 12 33 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 12 34 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 12 35    (n)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 13  1    (o)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 13  2 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 13  3 a defense.
 13  4    (p)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses by
 13  5 the defendant.
 13  6    (q)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 13  7 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 13  8 appreciate risks and consequences.
 13  9    (r)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 13 10 defendant.
 13 11    (s)  The circumstances of the murder including the extent
 13 12 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way
 13 13 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 13 14    (t)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 13 15 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 13 16 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.
 13 21    2.  a.  Notwithstanding subsection 1 and section 902.1, a
 13 22 defendant convicted of a class "A" felony, other than murder
 13 23 in the first degree in violation of section 707.2, and who was
 13 24 under the age of eighteen at the time the offense was committed
 13 25 shall receive one of the following sentences:
 13 26    (1)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 13 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 13 30    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.
 15 16    3.  If a defendant is paroled pursuant to subsection 1 or 2,
 15 17 the defendant shall be subject to the same set of procedures
 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.

 12 23    (ii)  The number of victims.
 12 24    (iii)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the murder,
 12 25 including whether the murder was the result of torture.
 12 26    (i)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 12 27 criminality of the conduct.
 12 28    (j)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 12 29 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 12 30    (k)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 12 31    (l)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 12 32    (m)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 12 33 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 12 34 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 12 35    (n)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 13  1    (o)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 13  2 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 13  3 a defense.
 13  4    (p)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses by
 13  5 the defendant.
 13  6    (q)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 13  7 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 13  8 appreciate risks and consequences.
 13  9    (r)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 13 10 defendant.
 13 11    (s)  The circumstances of the murder including the extent
 13 12 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way
 13 13 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 13 14    (t)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 13 15 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 13 16 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.
 13 21    2.  a.  Notwithstanding subsection 1 and section 902.1, a
 13 22 defendant convicted of a class "A" felony, other than murder
 13 23 in the first degree in violation of section 707.2, and who was
 13 24 under the age of eighteen at the time the offense was committed
 13 25 shall receive one of the following sentences:
 13 26    (1)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 13 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 13 30    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.

 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency

 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features

 12 11    (b)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 12 12    (c)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 12 13 posed by the defendant.
 12 14    (d)  The degree of participation in the murder by the
 12 15 defendant.
 12 16    (e)  The nature of the offense.
 12 17    (f)  The defendant's remorse.
 12 18    (g)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 12 19    (h)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 12 20 following:
 12 21    (i)  The commission of the murder while participating in
 12 22 another felony.
 12 23    (ii)  The number of victims.
 12 24    (iii)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the murder,
 12 25 including whether the murder was the result of torture.
 12 26    (i)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 12 27 criminality of the conduct.
 12 28    (j)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 12 29 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 12 30    (k)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 12 31    (l)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 12 32    (m)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 12 33 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 12 34 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 12 35    (n)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 13  1    (o)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 13  2 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 13  3 a defense.
 13  4    (p)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses by
 13  5 the defendant.
 13  6    (q)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 13  7 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 13  8 appreciate risks and consequences.
 13  9    (r)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 13 10 defendant.
 13 11    (s)  The circumstances of the murder including the extent
 13 12 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way
 13 13 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 13 14    (t)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 13 15 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 13 16 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.

 12 16    (e)  The nature of the offense.
 12 17    (f)  The defendant's remorse.
 12 18    (g)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 12 19    (h)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 12 20 following:
 12 21    (i)  The commission of the murder while participating in
 12 22 another felony.
 12 23    (ii)  The number of victims.
 12 24    (iii)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the murder,
 12 25 including whether the murder was the result of torture.
 12 26    (i)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 12 27 criminality of the conduct.
 12 28    (j)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 12 29 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 12 30    (k)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 12 31    (l)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 12 32    (m)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 12 33 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 12 34 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 12 35    (n)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 13  1    (o)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 13  2 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 13  3 a defense.
 13  4    (p)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses by
 13  5 the defendant.
 13  6    (q)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 13  7 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 13  8 appreciate risks and consequences.
 13  9    (r)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 13 10 defendant.
 13 11    (s)  The circumstances of the murder including the extent
 13 12 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way
 13 13 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 13 14    (t)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 13 15 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 13 16 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.

 13  1    (o)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 13  2 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 13  3 a defense.
 13  4    (p)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses by
 13  5 the defendant.
 13  6    (q)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 13  7 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 13  8 appreciate risks and consequences.
 13  9    (r)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 13 10 defendant.
 13 11    (s)  The circumstances of the murder including the extent
 13 12 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way
 13 13 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 13 14    (t)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 13 15 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 13 16 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.

 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.

 14  8 posed by the defendant.

 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.

 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.
 15 16    3.  If a defendant is paroled pursuant to subsection 1 or 2,
 15 17 the defendant shall be subject to the same set of procedures
 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.

 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.
 15 20    Sec. 10.   12  7 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 12  8 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 12  9 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 12 10 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 12 11    (b)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 12 12    (c)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 12 13 posed by the defendant.
 12 14    (d)  The degree of participation in the murder by the
 12 15 defendant.
 12 16    (e)  The nature of the offense.
 12 17    (f)  The defendant's remorse.
 12 18    (g)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 12 19    (h)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 12 20 following:
 12 21    (i)  The commission of the murder while participating in
 12 22 another felony.
 12 23    (ii)  The number of victims.
 12 24    (iii)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the murder,
 12 25 including whether the murder was the result of torture.
 12 26    (i)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 12 27 criminality of the conduct.
 12 28    (j)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 12 29 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 12 30    (k)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 12 31    (l)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 12 32    (m)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 12 33 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 12 34 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 12 35    (n)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 13  1    (o)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 13  2 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 13  3 a defense.
 13  4    (p)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses by
 13  5 the defendant.
 13  6    (q)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 13  7 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 13  8 appreciate risks and consequences.
 13  9    (r)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 13 10 defendant.
 13 11    (s)  The circumstances of the murder including the extent
 13 12 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way
 13 13 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 13 14    (t)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 13 15 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 13 16 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.

 13 22 defendant convicted of a class "A" felony, other than murder
 13 23 in the first degree in violation of section 707.2, and who was
 13 24 under the age of eighteen at the time the offense was committed
 13 25 shall receive one of the following sentences:
 13 26    (1)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 13 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 13 30    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.

 15 17 the defendant shall be subject to the same set of procedures
 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.

 13 25 shall receive one of the following sentences:
 13 26    (1)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 13 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 13 30    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.
 15 16    3.  If a defendant is paroled pursuant to subsection 1 or 2,
 15 17 the defendant shall be subject to the same set of procedures
 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.

 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.

 13  6    (q)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 13  7 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 13  8 appreciate risks and consequences.
 13  9    (r)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 13 10 defendant.
 13 11    (s)  The circumstances of the murder including the extent
 13 12 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way
 13 13 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 13 14    (t)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 13 15 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 13 16 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.

 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.

 13 21    2.  a.  Notwithstanding subsection 1 and section 902.1, a
 13 22 defendant convicted of a class "A" felony, other than murder
 13 23 in the first degree in violation of section 707.2, and who was
 13 24 under the age of eighteen at the time the offense was committed
 13 25 shall receive one of the following sentences:
