 13 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 13 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 13 30    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.

 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.

 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.

 13 23 in the first degree in violation of section 707.2, and who was
 13 24 under the age of eighteen at the time the offense was committed
 13 25 shall receive one of the following sentences:
 13 26    (1)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 13 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 13 30    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.
 15 16    3.  If a defendant is paroled pursuant to subsection 1 or 2,
 15 17 the defendant shall be subject to the same set of procedures
 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.
 15 20    Sec. 10.   13 17 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 13 18    (u)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 13 19    (v)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 13 20 sentencing court.

 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.
 15 16    3.  If a defendant is paroled pursuant to subsection 1 or 2,
 15 17 the defendant shall be subject to the same set of procedures
 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.
 15 20    Sec. 10.   13 24 under the age of eighteen at the time the offense was committed
 13 25 shall receive one of the following sentences:
 13 26    (1)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 27 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 28 with the possibility of parole after serving a minimum term of
 13 29 confinement as determined by the court.
 13 30    (2)  Commitment to the custody of the director of the
 13 31 department of corrections for the rest of the defendant's life
 13 32 with the possibility of parole.
 13 33    b.  In determining which sentence to impose, the court shall
 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.

 13 34 consider all circumstances including but not limited to the
 13 35 following:
 14  1    (1)  The impact of the offense on each victim, as defined in
 14  2 section 915.10, through the use of a victim impact statement,
 14  3 as defined in section 915.10, under any format permitted by
 14  4 section 915.13. The victim impact statement may include
 14  5 comment on the sentence of the defendant.
 14  6    (2)  The impact of the offense on the community.
 14  7    (3)  The threat to the safety of the public or any individual
 14  8 posed by the defendant.
 14  9    (4)  The degree of participation in the offense by the
 14 10 defendant.
 14 11    (5)  The nature of the offense.
 14 12    (6)  The defendant's remorse.
 14 13    (7)  The defendant's acceptance of responsibility.
 14 14    (8)  The severity of the offense, including any of the
 14 15 following:
 14 16    (a)  The commission of the offense while participating in
 14 17 another felony.
 14 18    (b)  The number of victims.
 14 19    (c)  The heinous, brutal, cruel manner of the offense,
 14 20 including whether the offense involved torture.
 14 21    (9)  The capacity of the defendant to appreciate the
 14 22 criminality of the conduct.
 14 23    (10)  Whether the ability to conform the defendant's conduct
 14 24 with the requirements of the law was substantially impaired.
 14 25    (11)  The level of maturity of the defendant.
 14 26    (12)  The intellectual and mental capacity of the defendant.
 14 27    (13)  The nature and extent of any prior juvenile delinquency
 14 28 or criminal history of the defendant, including the success or
 14 29 failure of previous attempts at rehabilitation.
 14 30    (14)  The mental health history of the defendant.
 14 31    (15)  The level of compulsion, duress, or influence exerted
 14 32 upon the defendant, but not to such an extent as to constitute
 14 33 a defense.
 14 34    (16)  The likelihood of the commission of further offenses
 14 35 by the defendant.
 15  1    (17)  The chronological age of the defendant and the features
 15  2 of youth, including immaturity, impetuosity, and failure to
 15  3 appreciate risks and consequences.
 15  4    (18)  The family and home environment that surrounded the
 15  5 defendant.
 15  6    (19)  The circumstances of the offense including the extent
 15  7 of the defendant's participation in the conduct and the way the
 15  8 familial and peer pressure may have affected the defendant.
 15  9    (20)  The competencies associated with youth, including but
 15 10 not limited to the defendant's inability to deal with peace
 15 11 officers or the prosecution or the defendant's incapacity to
 15 12 assist the defendant's attorney in the defendant's defense.
 15 13    (21)  The possibility of rehabilitation.
 15 14    (22)  Any other information considered relevant by the
 15 15 sentencing court.
 15 16    3.  If a defendant is paroled pursuant to subsection 1 or 2,
 15 17 the defendant shall be subject to the same set of procedures
 15 18 set out in chapters 901B, 905, 906, and 908, and rules adopted
 15 19 under those chapters for persons on parole.

 15 20    Sec. 10.   15 20    Sec. 10.   15 21 penalty.
 15 22    Notwithstanding section 902.1, upon return of a plea or
 15 23 verdict of guilty to the multiple offense of murder in the
 15 24 first degree, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 15 25 902.15, and a return of a verdict in favor of a sentence of
 15 26 death in a penalty proceeding conducted as provided in section
 15 27 901D.1, the court shall enter a judgment of conviction and
 15 28 shall commit the defendant into the custody of the director
 15 29 of the Iowa department of corrections.  The sentence shall
 15 30 be carried out by the administration of a lethal injection
 15 31 pursuant to rules adopted by the board of corrections.  If
 15 32 a defendant, for whom a warrant of execution is issued, is
 15 33 pregnant, the execution shall not take place until after the
 15 34 defendant is no longer pregnant.  If a defendant, for whom
 15 35 a warrant of execution is issued, is suffering from such a
 16  1 diseased or deranged condition of the mind as to prevent the
 16  2 defendant from knowing the nature and quality of the act
 16  3 the defendant has been convicted of, or from understanding
 16  4 that trial on the offense has taken place and that execution
 16  5 proceedings are about to take place, or otherwise causes the
 16  6 defendant to lack the capacity to understand the sentence which
 16  7 has been imposed and to participate in any legal proceedings
 16  8 relating to the sentence, the execution shall not take place
 16  9 until after the defendant's capacity is restored.  If the
 16 10 director of the department of corrections or the defendant's
 16 11 counsel files a request with the court which issued the warrant
 16 12 of execution, alleging that the defendant suffers from such a
 16 13 diseased or deranged condition, a hearing on the matter shall
 16 14 be held in the manner provided in section 812A.1.  For the
 16 15 purposes of this section, "lethal injection" means a continuous
 16 16 intravenous injection of a lethal substance sufficient to cause
 16 17 death.

 16  5 proceedings are about to take place, or otherwise causes the
 16  6 defendant to lack the capacity to understand the sentence which
 16  7 has been imposed and to participate in any legal proceedings
 16  8 relating to the sentence, the execution shall not take place
 16  9 until after the defendant's capacity is restored.  If the
 16 10 director of the department of corrections or the defendant's
 16 11 counsel files a request with the court which issued the warrant
 16 12 of execution, alleging that the defendant suffers from such a
 16 13 diseased or deranged condition, a hearing on the matter shall
 16 14 be held in the manner provided in section 812A.1.  For the
 16 15 purposes of this section, "lethal injection" means a continuous
 16 16 intravenous injection of a lethal substance sufficient to cause
 16 17 death.

 16 18    Sec. 11.   16 18    Sec. 11.   16 19 offense of first degree murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse.
 16 20    A person who commits the multiple offense of murder in the
 16 21 first degree, kidnapping, and sexual abuse with respect to the
 16 22 same victim, who is not intellectually disabled or mentally
 16 23 ill, and who is age eighteen or older at the time the offense
 16 24 is committed, shall be eligible for a sentence of death under
 16 25 section 902.1B, if the victim was a minor.
 16 26    For purposes of this section, "intellectually disabled"
 16 27 means significant subaverage general intellectual functioning
 16 28 accompanied by significant deficits or impairments in adaptive
 16 29 functioning manifested in the developmental period, but no
 16 30 later than the age of eighteen years, and accompanied by
 16 31 deficits in adaptive behavior.
 16 32    For purposes of this section, "mentally ill" means the
 16 33 condition of a person who is suffering from a chronic and
 16 34 persistent serious mental disease or disorder and who, by
 16 35 reason of that condition, lacks sufficient judgment to make
 17  1 responsible decisions regarding treatment and is reasonably
 17  2 likely to injure the person's self or others who may come into
 17  3 contact with the person if the person is allowed to remain at
 17  4 liberty without treatment.

 17  7    1.  The supreme court shall collect data on all multiple
 17  8 offenses of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse charges in
 17  9 which the death penalty is or was not waived, which are filed
 17 10 and processed in the courts in this state.  This data may be
 17 11 used by the supreme court to determine whether death sentences
 17 12 imposed are excessive or disproportionate, or under the
 17 13 influence of prejudice under section 814.28.  The court shall
 17 14 make this data available to litigants in death penalty cases.
 17 15    2.  Data collected by public officials concerning factors
 17 16 relevant to the imposition of the death sentence shall be made
 17 17 publicly available.

 17 18    Sec. 13.   17 18    Sec. 13.   17 19 perform.
 17 20    An employee of the state who may lawfully perform, assist, or
 17 21 participate in the execution of a person pursuant to section
 17 22 902.1B, and rules adopted by the department of corrections,
 17 23 shall not be required to perform, assist, or participate in
 17 24 the execution.  State employees who refuse to perform, assist,
 17 25 or participate in the execution of a person shall not be
 17 26 discriminated against in any way, including but not limited
 17 27 to employment, promotion, advancement, transfer, licensing,
 17 28 education, training, or the granting of any privileges or
 17 29 appointments because of the refusal to perform, assist, or
 17 30 participate in the execution.
 17 31    Sec. 14.  Section 904.105, Code 2017, is amended by adding
 17 32 the following new subsection:
 17 33     17 20    An employee of the state who may lawfully perform, assist, or
 17 21 participate in the execution of a person pursuant to section
 17 22 902.1B, and rules adopted by the department of corrections,
 17 23 shall not be required to perform, assist, or participate in
 17 24 the execution.  State employees who refuse to perform, assist,
 17 25 or participate in the execution of a person shall not be
 17 26 discriminated against in any way, including but not limited
 17 27 to employment, promotion, advancement, transfer, licensing,
 17 28 education, training, or the granting of any privileges or
 17 29 appointments because of the refusal to perform, assist, or
 17 30 participate in the execution.

 17 27 to employment, promotion, advancement, transfer, licensing,
 17 28 education, training, or the granting of any privileges or
 17 29 appointments because of the refusal to perform, assist, or
 17 30 participate in the execution.
 17 31    Sec. 14.  Section 904.105, Code 2017, is amended by adding
 17 32 the following new subsection:
 17 33     17 26 discriminated against in any way, including but not limited
 17 27 to employment, promotion, advancement, transfer, licensing,
 17 28 education, training, or the granting of any privileges or
 17 29 appointments because of the refusal to perform, assist, or
 17 30 participate in the execution.

 17 32 the following new subsection:
 17 33     17 27 to employment, promotion, advancement, transfer, licensing,
 17 28 education, training, or the granting of any privileges or
 17 29 appointments because of the refusal to perform, assist, or
 17 30 participate in the execution.

 17 32 the following new subsection:
 17 33     17 28 education, training, or the granting of any privileges or
 17 29 appointments because of the refusal to perform, assist, or
 17 30 participate in the execution.

 17 32 the following new subsection:

 17 30 participate in the execution.

 17 32 the following new subsection:
 17 33     17 32 the following new subsection:
 17 33     17 33     17 34 pertaining to executions of persons convicted of the multiple
 17 35 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 18  1 902.15.  Rules adopted shall include but are not limited to
 18  2 rules permitting the witnessing of executions by members of
 18  3 the public and the victim's family.  Invitations to witness
 18  4 an execution shall at least be extended to the following
 18  5 representatives of the news media:
 18  6    a.  A representative from a wire service serving Iowa.
 18  7    b.  A representative from a broadcasting network serving
 18  8 Iowa.
 18  9    c.  A representative from a television station located in
 18 10 Iowa.
 18 11    d.  A representative from a radio station located in Iowa.
 18 12    e.  A representative from a daily newspaper published in
 18 13 Iowa.
 18 14    f.  A representative from a weekly newspaper published in
 18 15 Iowa.
 18 16    g.  A representative from the news media from the community
 18 17 in which the condemned person resided, if that community is
 18 18 located in Iowa.
 18 19    Sec. 15.  IMPLEMENTATION OF ACT.  Section 25B.2, subsection
 18 20 3, shall not apply to this Act.
 18 21    Sec. 16.  SEVERABILITY.  If any provision of this Act or the
 18 22 application thereof to any person is invalid, the invalidity
 18 23 shall not affect the provisions or application of this Act
 18 24 which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or
 18 25 application and to this end, the provisions of this Act are
 18 26 severable.
 18 27    Sec. 17.  EFFECTIVE DATE.  This Act takes effect January 1,
 18 28 2018.
 18 29    Sec. 18.  APPLICABILITY.  This Act applies to offenses
 18 30 committed on or after the effective date of this Act.
 18 31                           EXPLANATION
 18 32 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 18 33 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 18 34    This bill amends the Iowa criminal code to provide for
 18 35 punishment by death for the multiple offense of murder in the
 19  1 first degree, kidnapping, and sexual abuse committed by a
 19  2 person age 18 or older with respect to the same victim who is a
 19  3 minor if the trial jury, or the judge if there is no jury, makes
 19  4 specific findings and whether the jury believes the defendant
 19  5 should be put to death in a separate penalty proceeding held
 19  6 after the close of the initial trial proceeding.  Under the
 19  7 bill, a death sentence could be imposed if the murder would
 19  8 constitute murder in the first degree and the state pleads and
 19  9 proves the defendant also kidnapped and committed sexual abuse
 19 10 against the murder victim who was a minor.
 19 11    The bill provides that in order to receive a sentence of
 19 12 death, the defendant must be at least 18 years of age at the
 19 13 time the offense is committed, must not be mentally ill or
 19 14 intellectually disabled, and must have been a major participant
 19 15 in the commission of the crime or must have shown a manifest
 19 16 indifference to human life.
 19 17    If a person is indigent and is charged with capital murder,
 19 18 payment of costs for two attorneys is authorized.  The supreme
 19 19 court is required to establish standards for the competency of
 19 20 counsel in death penalty cases.  The state public defender is
 19 21 charged with establishing teams of qualified lead and cocounsel
 19 22 for death penalty cases, as well as conducting or sponsoring
 19 23 specialized training programs for attorneys representing
 19 24 persons who may be executed.
 19 25    If such a case proceeds to trial and a notice of intent
 19 26 to seek the death penalty has been filed, in addition to
 19 27 any other defenses which may be presented to the charge, the
 19 28 defendant may raise the issue of intellectual disability or
 19 29 mental illness during the time of filing pretrial motions,
 19 30 and the defendant is entitled to a rebuttable presumption of
 19 31 intellectual disability if the defendant establishes that the
 19 32 defendant has an intelligence quotient of 75 or below.
 19 33    Once the evidence is submitted to the jury, the court
 19 34 will instruct the jury, at the defendant's request, that in
 19 35 considering whether a sentence of death is justified, the
 20  1 race, color, religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other
 20  2 protected classes under Code chapter 216 of the defendant or
 20  3 of any victim is not to be considered.  The supreme court
 20  4 shall collect evidence relating to whether the death sentences
 20  5 imposed are excessive, disproportionate, or imposed under the
 20  6 influence of prejudice at trial which will be available to
 20  7 litigants.
 20  8    The sentence of death is imposed only when the trier of fact
 20  9 (the jury or the court if the defendant has waived the right to
 20 10 a jury trial) unanimously answers two questions affirmatively:
 20 11 (1) whether aggravating circumstances established beyond a
 20 12 reasonable doubt outweigh any mitigating circumstances that
 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
       LSB 1303XS (4) 87
       jm/rj
 17 35 offense of murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse under section
 18  1 902.15.  Rules adopted shall include but are not limited to
 18  2 rules permitting the witnessing of executions by members of
 18  3 the public and the victim's family.  Invitations to witness
 18  4 an execution shall at least be extended to the following
 18  5 representatives of the news media:
 18  6    a.  A representative from a wire service serving Iowa.
 18  7    b.  A representative from a broadcasting network serving
 18  8 Iowa.
 18  9    c.  A representative from a television station located in
 18 10 Iowa.
 18 11    d.  A representative from a radio station located in Iowa.
 18 12    e.  A representative from a daily newspaper published in
 18 13 Iowa.
 18 14    f.  A representative from a weekly newspaper published in
 18 15 Iowa.
 18 16    g.  A representative from the news media from the community
 18 17 in which the condemned person resided, if that community is
 18 18 located in Iowa.
 18 19    Sec. 15.  IMPLEMENTATION OF ACT.  Section 25B.2, subsection
 18 20 3, shall not apply to this Act.
 18 21    Sec. 16.  SEVERABILITY.  If any provision of this Act or the
 18 22 application thereof to any person is invalid, the invalidity
 18 23 shall not affect the provisions or application of this Act
 18 24 which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or
 18 25 application and to this end, the provisions of this Act are
 18 26 severable.
 18 27    Sec. 17.  EFFECTIVE DATE.  This Act takes effect January 1,
 18 28 2018.
 18 29    Sec. 18.  APPLICABILITY.  This Act applies to offenses
 18 30 committed on or after the effective date of this Act.

 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
       LSB 1303XS (4) 87
       jm/rj
 18  3 the public and the victim's family.  Invitations to witness
 18  4 an execution shall at least be extended to the following
 18  5 representatives of the news media:
 18  6    a.  A representative from a wire service serving Iowa.
 18  7    b.  A representative from a broadcasting network serving
 18  8 Iowa.
 18  9    c.  A representative from a television station located in
 18 10 Iowa.
 18 11    d.  A representative from a radio station located in Iowa.
 18 12    e.  A representative from a daily newspaper published in
 18 13 Iowa.
 18 14    f.  A representative from a weekly newspaper published in
 18 15 Iowa.
 18 16    g.  A representative from the news media from the community
 18 17 in which the condemned person resided, if that community is
 18 18 located in Iowa.
 18 19    Sec. 15.  IMPLEMENTATION OF ACT.  Section 25B.2, subsection
 18 20 3, shall not apply to this Act.
 18 21    Sec. 16.  SEVERABILITY.  If any provision of this Act or the
 18 22 application thereof to any person is invalid, the invalidity
 18 23 shall not affect the provisions or application of this Act
 18 24 which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or
 18 25 application and to this end, the provisions of this Act are
 18 26 severable.
 18 27    Sec. 17.  EFFECTIVE DATE.  This Act takes effect January 1,
 18 28 2018.
 18 29    Sec. 18.  APPLICABILITY.  This Act applies to offenses
 18 30 committed on or after the effective date of this Act.
 18 31                           EXPLANATION
 18 32 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 18 33 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 18 34    This bill amends the Iowa criminal code to provide for
 18 35 punishment by death for the multiple offense of murder in the
 19  1 first degree, kidnapping, and sexual abuse committed by a
 19  2 person age 18 or older with respect to the same victim who is a
 19  3 minor if the trial jury, or the judge if there is no jury, makes
 19  4 specific findings and whether the jury believes the defendant
 19  5 should be put to death in a separate penalty proceeding held
 19  6 after the close of the initial trial proceeding.  Under the
 19  7 bill, a death sentence could be imposed if the murder would
 19  8 constitute murder in the first degree and the state pleads and
 19  9 proves the defendant also kidnapped and committed sexual abuse
 19 10 against the murder victim who was a minor.
 19 11    The bill provides that in order to receive a sentence of
 19 12 death, the defendant must be at least 18 years of age at the
 19 13 time the offense is committed, must not be mentally ill or
 19 14 intellectually disabled, and must have been a major participant
 19 15 in the commission of the crime or must have shown a manifest
 19 16 indifference to human life.
 19 17    If a person is indigent and is charged with capital murder,
 19 18 payment of costs for two attorneys is authorized.  The supreme
 19 19 court is required to establish standards for the competency of
 19 20 counsel in death penalty cases.  The state public defender is
 19 21 charged with establishing teams of qualified lead and cocounsel
 19 22 for death penalty cases, as well as conducting or sponsoring
 19 23 specialized training programs for attorneys representing
 19 24 persons who may be executed.
 19 25    If such a case proceeds to trial and a notice of intent
 19 26 to seek the death penalty has been filed, in addition to
 19 27 any other defenses which may be presented to the charge, the
 19 28 defendant may raise the issue of intellectual disability or
 19 29 mental illness during the time of filing pretrial motions,
 19 30 and the defendant is entitled to a rebuttable presumption of
 19 31 intellectual disability if the defendant establishes that the
 19 32 defendant has an intelligence quotient of 75 or below.
 19 33    Once the evidence is submitted to the jury, the court
 19 34 will instruct the jury, at the defendant's request, that in
 19 35 considering whether a sentence of death is justified, the
 20  1 race, color, religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other
 20  2 protected classes under Code chapter 216 of the defendant or
 20  3 of any victim is not to be considered.  The supreme court
 20  4 shall collect evidence relating to whether the death sentences
 20  5 imposed are excessive, disproportionate, or imposed under the
 20  6 influence of prejudice at trial which will be available to
 20  7 litigants.
 20  8    The sentence of death is imposed only when the trier of fact
 20  9 (the jury or the court if the defendant has waived the right to
 20 10 a jury trial) unanimously answers two questions affirmatively:
 20 11 (1) whether aggravating circumstances established beyond a
 20 12 reasonable doubt outweigh any mitigating circumstances that
 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.

 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.

 18  7    b.  A representative from a broadcasting network serving
 18  8 Iowa.
 18  9    c.  A representative from a television station located in
 18 10 Iowa.
 18 11    d.  A representative from a radio station located in Iowa.
 18 12    e.  A representative from a daily newspaper published in
 18 13 Iowa.
 18 14    f.  A representative from a weekly newspaper published in
 18 15 Iowa.
 18 16    g.  A representative from the news media from the community
 18 17 in which the condemned person resided, if that community is
 18 18 located in Iowa.
 18 19    Sec. 15.  IMPLEMENTATION OF ACT.  Section 25B.2, subsection
 18 20 3, shall not apply to this Act.
 18 21    Sec. 16.  SEVERABILITY.  If any provision of this Act or the
 18 22 application thereof to any person is invalid, the invalidity
 18 23 shall not affect the provisions or application of this Act
 18 24 which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or
 18 25 application and to this end, the provisions of this Act are
 18 26 severable.
 18 27    Sec. 17.  EFFECTIVE DATE.  This Act takes effect January 1,
 18 28 2018.
 18 29    Sec. 18.  APPLICABILITY.  This Act applies to offenses
 18 30 committed on or after the effective date of this Act.
 18 31                           EXPLANATION
 18 32 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 18 33 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 18 34    This bill amends the Iowa criminal code to provide for
 18 35 punishment by death for the multiple offense of murder in the
 19  1 first degree, kidnapping, and sexual abuse committed by a
 19  2 person age 18 or older with respect to the same victim who is a
 19  3 minor if the trial jury, or the judge if there is no jury, makes
 19  4 specific findings and whether the jury believes the defendant
 19  5 should be put to death in a separate penalty proceeding held
 19  6 after the close of the initial trial proceeding.  Under the
 19  7 bill, a death sentence could be imposed if the murder would
 19  8 constitute murder in the first degree and the state pleads and
 19  9 proves the defendant also kidnapped and committed sexual abuse
 19 10 against the murder victim who was a minor.
 19 11    The bill provides that in order to receive a sentence of
 19 12 death, the defendant must be at least 18 years of age at the
 19 13 time the offense is committed, must not be mentally ill or
 19 14 intellectually disabled, and must have been a major participant
 19 15 in the commission of the crime or must have shown a manifest
 19 16 indifference to human life.
 19 17    If a person is indigent and is charged with capital murder,
 19 18 payment of costs for two attorneys is authorized.  The supreme
 19 19 court is required to establish standards for the competency of
 19 20 counsel in death penalty cases.  The state public defender is
 19 21 charged with establishing teams of qualified lead and cocounsel
 19 22 for death penalty cases, as well as conducting or sponsoring
 19 23 specialized training programs for attorneys representing
 19 24 persons who may be executed.
 19 25    If such a case proceeds to trial and a notice of intent
 19 26 to seek the death penalty has been filed, in addition to
 19 27 any other defenses which may be presented to the charge, the
 19 28 defendant may raise the issue of intellectual disability or
 19 29 mental illness during the time of filing pretrial motions,
 19 30 and the defendant is entitled to a rebuttable presumption of
 19 31 intellectual disability if the defendant establishes that the
 19 32 defendant has an intelligence quotient of 75 or below.
 19 33    Once the evidence is submitted to the jury, the court
 19 34 will instruct the jury, at the defendant's request, that in
 19 35 considering whether a sentence of death is justified, the
 20  1 race, color, religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other
 20  2 protected classes under Code chapter 216 of the defendant or
 20  3 of any victim is not to be considered.  The supreme court
 20  4 shall collect evidence relating to whether the death sentences
 20  5 imposed are excessive, disproportionate, or imposed under the
 20  6 influence of prejudice at trial which will be available to
 20  7 litigants.
 20  8    The sentence of death is imposed only when the trier of fact
 20  9 (the jury or the court if the defendant has waived the right to
 20 10 a jury trial) unanimously answers two questions affirmatively:
 20 11 (1) whether aggravating circumstances established beyond a
 20 12 reasonable doubt outweigh any mitigating circumstances that
 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.

 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.

 18 11    d.  A representative from a radio station located in Iowa.
 18 12    e.  A representative from a daily newspaper published in
 18 13 Iowa.
 18 14    f.  A representative from a weekly newspaper published in
 18 15 Iowa.
 18 16    g.  A representative from the news media from the community
 18 17 in which the condemned person resided, if that community is
 18 18 located in Iowa.

 18 20 3, shall not apply to this Act.
 18 21    Sec. 16.  SEVERABILITY.  If any provision of this Act or the
 18 22 application thereof to any person is invalid, the invalidity
 18 23 shall not affect the provisions or application of this Act
 18 24 which can be given effect without the invalid provisions or
 18 25 application and to this end, the provisions of this Act are
 18 26 severable.

 18 28 2018.
 18 29    Sec. 18.  APPLICABILITY.  This Act applies to offenses
 18 30 committed on or after the effective date of this Act.
 18 31                           EXPLANATION
 18 32 The inclusion of this explanation does not constitute agreement with
 18 33 the explanation's substance by the members of the general assembly.
 18 34    This bill amends the Iowa criminal code to provide for
 18 35 punishment by death for the multiple offense of murder in the
 19  1 first degree, kidnapping, and sexual abuse committed by a
 19  2 person age 18 or older with respect to the same victim who is a
 19  3 minor if the trial jury, or the judge if there is no jury, makes
 19  4 specific findings and whether the jury believes the defendant
 19  5 should be put to death in a separate penalty proceeding held
 19  6 after the close of the initial trial proceeding.  Under the
 19  7 bill, a death sentence could be imposed if the murder would
 19  8 constitute murder in the first degree and the state pleads and
 19  9 proves the defendant also kidnapped and committed sexual abuse
 19 10 against the murder victim who was a minor.
 19 11    The bill provides that in order to receive a sentence of
 19 12 death, the defendant must be at least 18 years of age at the
 19 13 time the offense is committed, must not be mentally ill or
 19 14 intellectually disabled, and must have been a major participant
 19 15 in the commission of the crime or must have shown a manifest
 19 16 indifference to human life.
 19 17    If a person is indigent and is charged with capital murder,
 19 18 payment of costs for two attorneys is authorized.  The supreme
 19 19 court is required to establish standards for the competency of
 19 20 counsel in death penalty cases.  The state public defender is
 19 21 charged with establishing teams of qualified lead and cocounsel
 19 22 for death penalty cases, as well as conducting or sponsoring
 19 23 specialized training programs for attorneys representing
 19 24 persons who may be executed.
 19 25    If such a case proceeds to trial and a notice of intent
 19 26 to seek the death penalty has been filed, in addition to
 19 27 any other defenses which may be presented to the charge, the
 19 28 defendant may raise the issue of intellectual disability or
 19 29 mental illness during the time of filing pretrial motions,
 19 30 and the defendant is entitled to a rebuttable presumption of
 19 31 intellectual disability if the defendant establishes that the
 19 32 defendant has an intelligence quotient of 75 or below.
 19 33    Once the evidence is submitted to the jury, the court
 19 34 will instruct the jury, at the defendant's request, that in
 19 35 considering whether a sentence of death is justified, the
 20  1 race, color, religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other
 20  2 protected classes under Code chapter 216 of the defendant or
 20  3 of any victim is not to be considered.  The supreme court
 20  4 shall collect evidence relating to whether the death sentences
 20  5 imposed are excessive, disproportionate, or imposed under the
 20  6 influence of prejudice at trial which will be available to
 20  7 litigants.
 20  8    The sentence of death is imposed only when the trier of fact
 20  9 (the jury or the court if the defendant has waived the right to
 20 10 a jury trial) unanimously answers two questions affirmatively:
 20 11 (1) whether aggravating circumstances established beyond a
 20 12 reasonable doubt outweigh any mitigating circumstances that
 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
