 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
       LSB 1303XS (4) 87
       jm/rj
 19 27 any other defenses which may be presented to the charge, the
 19 28 defendant may raise the issue of intellectual disability or
 19 29 mental illness during the time of filing pretrial motions,
 19 30 and the defendant is entitled to a rebuttable presumption of
 19 31 intellectual disability if the defendant establishes that the
 19 32 defendant has an intelligence quotient of 75 or below.
 19 33    Once the evidence is submitted to the jury, the court
 19 34 will instruct the jury, at the defendant's request, that in
 19 35 considering whether a sentence of death is justified, the
 20  1 race, color, religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other
 20  2 protected classes under Code chapter 216 of the defendant or
 20  3 of any victim is not to be considered.  The supreme court
 20  4 shall collect evidence relating to whether the death sentences
 20  5 imposed are excessive, disproportionate, or imposed under the
 20  6 influence of prejudice at trial which will be available to
 20  7 litigants.
 20  8    The sentence of death is imposed only when the trier of fact
 20  9 (the jury or the court if the defendant has waived the right to
 20 10 a jury trial) unanimously answers two questions affirmatively:
 20 11 (1) whether aggravating circumstances established beyond a
 20 12 reasonable doubt outweigh any mitigating circumstances that
 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.

 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
       LSB 1303XS (4) 87
       jm/rj
 19 34 will instruct the jury, at the defendant's request, that in
 19 35 considering whether a sentence of death is justified, the
 20  1 race, color, religious beliefs, national origin, sex, or other
 20  2 protected classes under Code chapter 216 of the defendant or
 20  3 of any victim is not to be considered.  The supreme court
 20  4 shall collect evidence relating to whether the death sentences
 20  5 imposed are excessive, disproportionate, or imposed under the
 20  6 influence of prejudice at trial which will be available to
 20  7 litigants.
 20  8    The sentence of death is imposed only when the trier of fact
 20  9 (the jury or the court if the defendant has waived the right to
 20 10 a jury trial) unanimously answers two questions affirmatively:
 20 11 (1) whether aggravating circumstances established beyond a
 20 12 reasonable doubt outweigh any mitigating circumstances that
 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.

 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
       LSB 1303XS (4) 87
       jm/rj
 20  7 litigants.
 20  8    The sentence of death is imposed only when the trier of fact
 20  9 (the jury or the court if the defendant has waived the right to
 20 10 a jury trial) unanimously answers two questions affirmatively:
 20 11 (1) whether aggravating circumstances established beyond a
 20 12 reasonable doubt outweigh any mitigating circumstances that
 20 13 may exist; and (2) whether the defendant should be sentenced
 20 14 to death.  Mitigating factors the trier of fact may consider
 20 15 include the following:  the defendant was under the influence
 20 16 of an extreme mental or emotional disturbance; the age of
 20 17 the defendant; the defendant's ability to appreciate the
 20 18 wrongfulness of the conduct due to mental disease but not
 20 19 to a degree to constitute a defense; the defendant has no
 20 20 significant prior criminal history; the defendant was under
 20 21 extreme duress; the defendant did not directly commit the
 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any

 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.

 20 22 murder, kidnapping, and sexual abuse; and the defendant's
 20 23 character or record or the circumstances of the offense.  The
 20 24 sentencing proceeding is conducted separately from the finding
 20 25 of guilt or innocence by the same trier of fact.
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.

 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
       LSB 1303XS (4) 87
       jm/rj
 20 26    For the sentencing proceeding, the trier of fact (the jury
 20 27 or the court if the defendant has waived the right to have
 20 28 the jury hear the proceedings) is to weigh any aggravating
 20 29 circumstances established beyond a reasonable doubt by the
 20 30 state against any of the enumerated mitigating circumstances
 20 31 which may be presented by the defendant.  Evidence of certain
 20 32 juvenile delinquency adjudications is not admissible in any
 20 33 proceeding to determine the sentence.  If the jury fails to
 20 34 agree unanimously on the required affirmative findings, the
 20 35 penalty imposed would be life imprisonment.
 21  1 The death penalty sentence would be reviewed automatically
 21  2 by the supreme court.  The supreme court shall review the trial
 21  3 and judgment separately from the sentencing proceeding.   If the
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.

 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.

       jm/rj
 21  4 supreme court finds error in the sentencing proceeding, the
 21  5 supreme court may remand the case back to district court for a
 21  6 new sentencing hearing.  The bill requires the supreme court to
 21  7 examine whether the sentence is excessive or disproportionate
 21  8 to penalties in similar cases.  If affirmed by the supreme
 21  9 court, the penalty would be accomplished by lethal injection.
 21 10 The bill requires the board of corrections to adopt rules
 21 11 pertaining to executions, including rules pertaining to the
 21 12 witnessing of executions.
 21 13    A person who is sentenced to death, but who is pregnant when
 21 14 the warrant of execution is issued, is not to be executed until
 21 15 the person is no longer pregnant.  A procedure is also provided
 21 16 to stay execution of a condemned inmate who becomes insane
 21 17 after conviction but before execution.
 21 18    An employee of the state shall not be required to perform or
 21 19 assist in any execution and shall not be discriminated against
 21 20 for refusing to participate.
 21 21    The bill strikes provisions in Code section 902.1(2), (3),
 21 22 and (4) relating to juvenile class "A" felons and reinserts the
 21 23 provisions unchanged in newly created Code section 902.1B in
 21 24 the bill. Juvenile felons are not subject to imposition of a
 21 25 sentence of death.
 21 26    The bill may include a state mandate as defined in Code
 21 27 section 25B.3.  The bill makes inapplicable Code section 25B.2,
 21 28 subsection 3, which would relieve a political subdivision from
 21 29 complying with a state mandate if funding for the cost of
 21 30 the state mandate is not provided or specified.  Therefore,
 21 31 political subdivisions are required to comply with any state
 21 32 mandate included in the bill.
 21 33    The bill contains severability provisions and takes effect
 21 34 January 1, 2018, and applies only to applicable offenses
 21 35 committed on or after that date.
